Factors

ag

Load tidyverse

Code 
library(tidyverse)
Code 
# create a bib file for the R packages
# used in this document
# Note! Needs to do a touch(ag_factors.bib) in terminal before first run
# else stops when bibliography: "ag_factors.bib" not found in YAML
knitr::write_bib(
  c(
    "tidyverse",
    "forcats"
    ),
  file = "ag_factors.bib"
  )

Factors

  • We have already encountered factors
  • Rs way of representing category variables
  • Efficent alternative to making a lot of dummy variables
  • R is perhaps a bit to eager, hence smart to remember the option stringsAsFactors for many functions.

    • Set this option to FALSE, default is TRUE. Reversed since R 4.1, default now FALSE.

    • Then convert the character vector manually to a factor with var <- factor(var) (base::factor) or better with the tidyverse alternative from forcats (var <- fct(var)) (forcat::fct).

  • The tidyverse functions will not convert to factor unless you ask for it.

Factors cont.

From help: "fct() is a stricter version of factor() that errors if your specification of levels is inconsistent with the values in x."

Code 
x <- c("cat", "dog", "dog", "cow", "cat", "coow")
# base factor()
x_bf <- factor(x, levels = c("cat", "dog", "cow"))
x_bf
[1] cat  dog  dog  cow  cat  <NA>
Levels: cat dog cow
Code 
# STRICTER; gives warning readr::parse_factor
x_rf <- parse_factor(x, levels = c("cat", "dog", "cow"))
x_rf
[1] cat  dog  dog  cow  cat  <NA>
attr(,"problems")
# A tibble: 1 × 4
    row   col expected           actual
  <int> <int> <chr>              <chr> 
1     6    NA value in level set coow  
Levels: cat dog cow

Factors cont.

  • fct() is very strict. Throws an error if value not in levels.
Code 
# STRICT; gives ERROR
forcat fct()
x_ff <- fct(x, levels = c("cat", "dog", "cow"))
Error in `fct()`:
! All values of `x` must appear in `levels` or `na`
ℹ Missing level: "coow"
  • You don’t have to specify levels.
  • If you don’t. Levels will be set to unique values in data, orderer as they first occur in data.

Factors

  • If you end up with a factor and want a numeric vector see R FAQ: 7.10 How do I convert factors to numeric?
    • v = as.numeric(levels(f))[as.integer(f)]
    • v = as.numeric(as.character(f)) also works, but less efficient
  • To make a factor manually you do:
    • my_df$variable_name <- factor(my_df$variable_name) or
    • use parse_factor() which is a safer alternative or
    • use fct() which is an even safer alternative.

Factors in tidyverse; forcats

  • Many of the functions in forcats are about reordering levels.
    • Cosmetic, for plots and tables
    • Results will not change
  • Important technique:
    • Make factor of a variable.
    • Collapse the levels into groups we are interested in and throw the rest into an "Other" category.
    • Alternative to case_when()

Example

  • Use dataset gss_cat in the forcats package as an example.
Code 
gss_cat <- forcats::gss_cat
gss_cat |> head(n = 5) |> print(width = 75)
# A tibble: 5 × 9
   year marital         age race  rincome       partyid relig denom tvhours
  <int> <fct>         <int> <fct> <fct>         <fct>   <fct> <fct>   <int>
1  2000 Never married    26 White $8000 to 9999 Ind,ne… Prot… Sout…      12
2  2000 Divorced         48 White $8000 to 9999 Not st… Prot… Bapt…      NA
3  2000 Widowed          67 White Not applicab… Indepe… Prot… No d…       2
4  2000 Never married    39 White Not applicab… Ind,ne… Orth… Not …       4
5  2000 Divorced         25 White Not applicab… Not st… None  Not …       1
  • Most already factors
  • Change patyid to character for illustration

Example; Change patyid to character

Code 
gss_cat <- gss_cat |>
  mutate(
    partyid = as.character(partyid)
  )
Code 
gss_cat |> head(n = 2) |> print(width = 75)
# A tibble: 2 × 9
   year marital         age race  rincome       partyid relig denom tvhours
  <int> <fct>         <int> <fct> <fct>         <chr>   <fct> <fct>   <int>
1  2000 Never married    26 White $8000 to 9999 Ind,ne… Prot… Sout…      12
2  2000 Divorced         48 White $8000 to 9999 Not st… Prot… Bapt…      NA

Example; Make factor of partyid

Code 
gss_cat <- gss_cat |> 
  mutate(
    partyid_fac = fct(partyid)
  )
Code 
gss_cat |> head(n = 2) |> print(width = 75)
# A tibble: 2 × 10
   year marital   age race  rincome partyid relig denom tvhours partyid_fac
  <int> <fct>   <int> <fct> <fct>   <chr>   <fct> <fct>   <int> <fct>      
1  2000 Never …    26 White $8000 … Ind,ne… Prot… Sout…      12 Ind,near r…
2  2000 Divorc…    48 White $8000 … Not st… Prot… Bapt…      NA Not str re…

Example; collapse levels

Code 
levels(gss_cat$partyid_fac)
 [1] "Ind,near rep"       "Not str republican" "Independent"       
 [4] "Not str democrat"   "Strong democrat"    "Ind,near dem"      
 [7] "Strong republican"  "Other party"        "No answer"         
[10] "Don't know"
  • Only want “Strong republican”, “Strong democrat” and all “Independent”s.
  • Put the rest into “Other”
Code 
gss_cat <- gss_cat |> 
  mutate(
    party = fct_collapse(
      .f = partyid_fac,
      "Strong rep" = "Strong republican",
      "Strong dem" = "Strong democrat",
      "Ind" = c("Independent", "Ind,near dem", "Ind,near rep"),
      other_level = "Other"
    )
  )

Example; new collapsed factor

Code 
gss_cat |> 
  select(year, partyid, partyid_fac, party) |>
  head(n = 10) |>
  print(width = 75)
# A tibble: 10 × 4
    year partyid            partyid_fac        party     
   <int> <chr>              <fct>              <fct>     
 1  2000 Ind,near rep       Ind,near rep       Ind       
 2  2000 Not str republican Not str republican Other     
 3  2000 Independent        Independent        Ind       
 4  2000 Ind,near rep       Ind,near rep       Ind       
 5  2000 Not str democrat   Not str democrat   Other     
 6  2000 Strong democrat    Strong democrat    Strong dem
 7  2000 Not str republican Not str republican Other     
 8  2000 Ind,near dem       Ind,near dem       Ind       
 9  2000 Not str democrat   Not str democrat   Other     
10  2000 Strong republican  Strong republican  Strong rep

Another factor example

  • forcats part of core tidyverse (i.e. library(tidyverse) will load forecats)
  • How to make a factor variable?
Code 
# Some alternatives Long Abbreviations for Days
x <- c("Mon", "Tue", "Tues", "Wed", "Thu", "Thur", "Thurs", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun")
set.seed(1234)
df_days <- tibble(
  days = sample(x, size = 100, replace = TRUE)
  )
df_days %>% table()
days
  Fri   Mon   Sat   Sun   Thu  Thur Thurs   Tue  Tues   Wed 
   11     7     8    11    10    17     6     6    11    13
  • Thursday is abbreviated in three different ways, while Tuesday are abbreviated in two different ways.

How to fix this

  • Change the values
Code 
# or use fct_collapse()
df_days <- df_days %>% 
  mutate(
    days = case_when(
      days %in% c("Tues") ~ "Tue",
      days %in% c("Thur") ~ "Thu",
      TRUE ~ days
    )
  )
df_days %>% table()
days
  Fri   Mon   Sat   Sun   Thu Thurs   Tue   Wed 
   11     7     8    11    27     6    17    13

How to fix this, cont.

Code 
# US standard; Sunday first day of the week
day_levels <- c("Sun", "Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat")
tmp_days <- df_days %>% 
  mutate(
    days_fixed = factor(days, levels = day_levels)
  ) %>%
  select(days_fixed)
Code 
tmp_days %>% 
  table() 
days_fixed
Sun Mon Tue Wed Thu Fri Sat 
 11   7  17  13  27  11   8
Code 
# Need a table before sum 
tmp_days %>% 
  table() %>% 
  sum()
[1] 94
  • 94?

How to fix this, cont.

  • 6 days have disappeared. What happend?
    • We forgot to change “Thurs” to “Thu”, so 6 of the 100 days did not match any level.
    • This is quietly ignored without any warning by factor().
      • This is dangerous!
  • Much safer to use parse_factor() from readr (warning for missing level) or fct() from forcats (error for missing level).

How to fix this, cont.

Code 
df_days <- df_days %>% 
  mutate(
    days_fixed = parse_factor(days, levels = day_levels)
  )
  • Gives the following warnings.
Warning: 6 parsing failures.
row col           expected actual
  9  -- value in level set  Thurs
 29  -- value in level set  Thurs
 59  -- value in level set  Thurs
 69  -- value in level set  Thurs
 73  -- value in level set  Thurs
... ... .................. ......
See problems(...) for more details.

How to fix this, cont.

  • parse_factor() gives us proper warnings.
  • After the warnings we can table again with the option useNA = "always".
Code 
table(df_days$days_fixed, useNA = "always")

 Sun  Mon  Tue  Wed  Thu  Fri  Sat <NA> 
  11    7   17   13   27   11    8    6

How to fix this, cont

  • Then we can fix our problem (add “Thurs”)
Code 
df_days <- df_days %>%
  mutate(
    days_fixed = parse_factor(
      case_when(
        days %in% c("Tues") ~ "Tue",
        days %in% c("Thur", "Thurs") ~ "Thu",
        # the others just like days
        TRUE ~ days
      ),
      levels = day_levels
    )
  )
df_days %>%
  select(days_fixed) %>%
  table(useNA = "always")
days_fixed
 Sun  Mon  Tue  Wed  Thu  Fri  Sat <NA> 
  11    7   17   13   33   11    8    0

Automatic levels

  • Note! The order of the levels is mainly of significance in visualisations, i.e. when we present our results
  • Above we specified the levels explicitly
  • Automatic levels:
    • Alphabetic order
    • When they first occur levels = unique(variable_name)
    • Fix it after creation with fct_inorder() that gives the order in which they first occur or
    • fct_infreq() according to frequency or
    • fct_inseq() according to value (numeric values) in combination with fct_rev() or
    • fct_reorder() for more general reorder, se r4ds 15.4 for example.

Automatic levels cont.

Code 
head(df_days$days_fixed, n = 5)
[1] Sun Thu Thu Sat Thu
Levels: Sun Mon Tue Wed Thu Fri Sat
Code 
df_days <- df_days %>%
  mutate(
    day_of_the_week = as.numeric(days_fixed)
  )
head(df_days$day_of_the_week, n = 5)
[1] 1 5 5 7 5

Automatic levels cont.

Code 
df_days <- df_days %>% 
  mutate(
    # first convert day_of_the_week to character
    day_of_the_week = as.character(day_of_the_week),
    # then convert day_of_the_week to factor
    day_of_the_week = parse_factor(day_of_the_week)
  )
df_days[1:6,]
# A tibble: 6 × 3
  days  days_fixed day_of_the_week
  <chr> <fct>      <fct>          
1 Sun   Sun        1              
2 Thu   Thu        5              
3 Thu   Thu        5              
4 Sat   Sat        7              
5 Thu   Thu        5              
6 Thu   Thu        5

Automatic levels cont.

Code 
levels(df_days$day_of_the_week)
[1] "1" "5" "7" "4" "3" "6" "2"
  • The ordering of the levels is determined by when a value occurs.

Automatic levels cont.

Code 
df_days$day_of_the_week <- fct_inseq(df_days$day_of_the_week)
levels(df_days$day_of_the_week)
[1] "1" "2" "3" "4" "5" "6" "7"
Code 
df_days %>% 
  filter(days_fixed == "Thu") %>% 
  head(n = 5)
# A tibble: 5 × 3
  days  days_fixed day_of_the_week
  <chr> <fct>      <fct>          
1 Thu   Thu        5              
2 Thu   Thu        5              
3 Thu   Thu        5              
4 Thu   Thu        5              
5 Thurs Thu        5
  • Levels are ordered after number.

fct_infreq()

Code 
df_days$day_of_the_week <- fct_infreq(df_days$day_of_the_week)
levels(df_days$day_of_the_week)
[1] "5" "3" "4" "1" "6" "7" "2"
  • Levels are ordered after how often they occur.

fct_inorder()

  • same as levels = unique(<factor_variable_name>)
Code 
df_days$day_of_the_week <- fct_inorder(df_days$day_of_the_week)
levels(df_days$day_of_the_week)
[1] "1" "5" "7" "4" "3" "6" "2"
  • Levels are ordered by the order in which they first appear.

Recoding factors

  • Perhaps we want to change the names of the different levels
  • fct_recode() can help
  • fct_relevel() change the ordering of the levels
Code 
# Norwegian abbreviations 
df_days <- df_days %>%
  mutate(
    days_nor = days_fixed,
    days_nor = fct_recode(days_nor,
      "søn" = "Sun",
      "man" = "Mon",
      "tir" = "Tue",
      "ons" = "Wed",
      "tor" = "Thu",
      "fre" = "Fri",
      "lør" = "Sat",
    ),
    # monday first day of week
    days_nor = fct_relevel(days_nor, "søn", after = 6)
  )
levels(df_days$days_nor)
[1] "man" "tir" "ons" "tor" "fre" "lør" "søn"

day_of_the_week_nor

Code 
# day of the week Norwegian standard, monday day 1
df_days <- df_days %>%
  mutate(
    # get the numeric values of the nor days, mon = 1 etc
    d_o_t_w_nor = as.numeric(days_nor),
    # convert to character to make categories
    d_o_t_w_nor = as.character(d_o_t_w_nor),
    # make a factor of it
    d_o_t_w_nor = parse_factor(d_o_t_w_nor),
    # sort the levels, "1", "2" ... "7"
    d_o_t_w_nor = fct_inseq(d_o_t_w_nor)
  )
levels(df_days$d_o_t_w_nor)
[1] "1" "2" "3" "4" "5" "6" "7"

Other functions

  • fct_rev(): used together with fct_infreq(). Reverses the ordering of the levels, i.e. “7”, “6” … “1”
  • fct_collapse(): collapses levels, several old levels into a new level (or into an old level)
  • fct_lump_min(): lumps levels that appear fewer than min. times.
  • fct_lump_prop(): lumps levels that appear in fewer prop * n times, for instance less than 3%
  • fct_lump_n(): lumps all levels except for the n most frequent (or least frequent if n < 0)
  • fct_lump_lowfreq(): lumps together the least frequent levels, ensuring that “other” is still the smallest level.
  • see ?fct_lump for examples
  • fct_other(): keep some levels, put the rest in an “other” category.

References

MSB105

Wickham, Hadley. 2023a. Forcats: Tools for Working with Categorical Variables (Factors). https://forcats.tidyverse.org/.
———. 2023b. Tidyverse: Easily Install and Load the Tidyverse. https://tidyverse.tidyverse.org.
Wickham, Hadley, Mara Averick, Jennifer Bryan, Winston Chang, Lucy D’Agostino McGowan, Romain François, Garrett Grolemund, et al. 2019. “Welcome to the tidyverse.” Journal of Open Source Software 4 (43): 1686. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686.
